I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation for a senior loan of 
up to $25 million (funded in local currency equivalent or US dollars) to Vietnam Technological 
and Commercial Joint-stock Bank (Techcombank). The loan will be used by Techcombank for 
mortgage lending for residential housing in primarily urban centers in Viet Nam. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: BACKGROUND, CHALLENGES, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Viet Nam’s Economy 

1. 

Overview and Outlook 

2. 
Viet  Nam  has  made  significant  gains  in  improving  its  economy  and  alleviating  poverty.  
During the period from 2003 to June 2006 it was the second fastest-growing economy in Asia, 
with gross domestic product (GDP) growth rates of between 7.0 and almost 8.5%.1  The GDP 
growth rate is expected to be about 8.2% for 2006.2  The World Bank notes that poverty levels 
have decreased from 70% to less than 20% currently. Real income levels have grown by about 
7% per year over the last 10 years.3  The Government is committed to making the transition to a 
market  economy  within  the  next  5  years  and  has  implemented  a  number  of  reforms.  As  a 
reflection of the improved investment climate, foreign direct investment (FDI) was approximately 
$10.2 billion in 2006.4  A current account surplus of 0.3% of GDP in 2006, combined with strong 
FDI flows, yielded Viet Nam’s highest foreign exchange reserves to date of $13.4 billion.5  The 
forecast average inflation rate for 2007 is 7.8%.6 
 
3. 
The  medium-term  outlook  for  Viet  Nam’s  economy  is  positive.  The  country’s  5-year 
target for 2006–2010 for GDP growth rates is between 7.5 and 8.0%. Viet Nam benefits from a 
number  of  factors  that  will  likely  sustain  the  strong  growth  rate:  (i)  a  young,  rapidly  growing 
workforce with literacy rates at 93%;7 (ii) strong growth opportunities in the manufacturing sector, 
which are supported by the Government’s continued reforms and which are expected to result in 
FDI at approximately $18 billion in 2008 (footnote 6); and (iii) membership in the World Trade 
Organization (WTO), which solidifies the progress the country has made and the Government’s 
commitment to reforms. Appendix 1 provides more detail on the country’s macroeconomic and 
political outlook. The country is rated BB– by Fitch Ratings, BB by Standard & Poor’s, and Ba2 
by Moody’s ratings agency.  
 

2. 

Challenges for the Future 

4. 
Viet Nam will need to address certain challenges in the medium-term in order to sustain 
its positive growth pattern.  It must control the government deficit and general government debt, 
and continue reforms in the state-owned enterprise (SOEs) and state-owned commercial bank 
(SOCBs)  sectors.  Government  revenues  have  been  strong  in  the  past  due  to  high  oil  prices.8

 2 

 

 

 

With the anticipated decrease in oil prices, however, and continued government expenditure on 
necessary  infrastructure  investments,  the  government  deficit  is  expected  to  increase  in  2007 
and 2008. The deficit amounted to 1.2% of GDP in 2006, and is projected to increase to 2.3% in 
2007 and 2.5% in 2008, and remain at approximately this level until 2011.9 SOE debt has been 
gradually  declining  to  about  29%  of  GDP  in  2006  and  is  expected  to  decline  further  as  the 
Government  moves  forward  with  its  plans  for  equitization  (footnote  6).  It  is  important  that  the 
Government hasten the pace of reform of SOEs and SOCBs to improve the overall performance 
of these entities, thereby reducing nonperforming loans (NPLs), and to assist them in adapting 
to  a  market  economy.  The  Government  has  introduced  policies  to  provide  a  comprehensive 
legal framework, which should help to increase the pace of equitization.  
 
B. 

The Banking Sector in Viet Nam 

1. 

Overview  

5. 
The  banking  sector in Viet  Nam  can  be  characterized  as small  in  terms  of  total assets 
(currently estimated at $40 billion), fragmented, and highly populated. As highlighted in ADB’s 
country strategy and program (CSP) (2007–2010), the financial sector is weak. Despite having 
approximately 80 banks, Viet Nam is dominated by five large SOCBs,10 and the historically poor 
performance of these institutions has weakened the banking sector, although it is beginning to 
show  some  signs  of  overall  improvement.  The  banking  sector  is  now  more  diversified  and 
includes joint-stock commercial banks (JSBs), foreign banks, and joint venture banks. There are 
also two development and policy banks and about 50 foreign bank representative offices. The 
State  Bank  of  Vietnam  (SBV)  acts  as  a  central  bank  and  supervisory  institution,  but  is  also  a 
shareholder  in  the  SOCBs.  Basel  I  standards 11  are  currently  in  place  and  the  SBV  aims  to 
implement  Basel  II  standards  in  2010.  However,  several  problem  areas,  such  as  successful 
capitalization,  equitization,  and  improvement  in  risk  management  of  the  SOCBs,  remain  to  be 
addressed. Appendix 2 provides additional details on the banking sector in Viet Nam. 
 
6. 
State-Owned Commercial Banks. The SOCBs control 75% of all banking assets in the 
market  (footnote  6).  The  SOCBs  were  originally  sectoral  departments  under  the  SBV  with 
specified lending programs (typically targeted to SOEs), which were often based on government 
policies. Most of these banks have suffered from inadequate risk management and poor asset 
quality  and,  therefore,  have  posed  a  risk  to  Viet  Nam’s  banking  system  and,  more  broadly,  to 
the  overall  economy.  Compounding  these  weaknesses  has  been  the  existence  of  poor 
disclosure and weak accounting standards. While the Government maintained that NPLs were 
at about 4%, it is more likely that they were around 15% (footnote 6). Most SOCBs did not meet 
international  capital  requirement  standards,  as  the  Government  did  not  apply  international 
standards,  but  rather  set  thresholds  for  the  banks.  The  average  capital  adequacy  ratio  for 
SOCBs  at  the  end  of  2005  was  4.5%.  With  the  exception  of  the  Mekong  Delta  Housing  Bank 
and  the  Vietnam  Bank  of  Foreign  Trade  (Vietcombank),  return  on  assets  (ROA)  for  most  of 
these banks has been lower than international industry averages.  
 

                                                 
9   Economist Intelligence Unit. 2007. Country Report: Vietnam. London. 
10  Bank  for  Agricultural  and  Rural  Development  of  Vietnam,  Bank  for  Investment  and  Development  of  Vietnam, 
Vietnam  Bank  for  Industry  and  Commerce,  Vietnam  Bank  of  Foreign  Trade,  and  Mekong  Delta  Housing 
Development Bank. 

11 Basel I standards which established the minimum capital requirements for banks were issued in 1988 by the Bank 
for  International  Settlements.  Basel  II  standards,  which  are  considered  to  be  more  comprehensive  are  in  the 
process of being implemented by several countries. Vietnam has not yet implemented Basel II standards.  

  

The performance of the SOCBs is starting to improve. Fitch Ratings recently upgraded 
7. 
the four largest SOCBs to D/E from E.12  The upgrade reflects the banks’ shift to more private-
sector lending and an overall improvement in profitability. The operational improvement of these 
banks is due in large part to changes undertaken in preparation for the equitization process. The 
Government  plans  to  equitize  all  of  the  banks,  with  the  exception  of  the  Vietnam  Bank  for 
Agriculture and Rural Development, in 2007 and 2008. Vietcombank will be the pilot bank under 
the equitization program. Banks have also embarked upon programs to reduce NPL levels and 
to  raise  capital  adequacy  ratios  to  levels  required  under  Basel  I  standards  and  in  accordance 
with international accounting standards. In order for most of these banks to do so, it is estimated 
that the Government will need to make cash infusions of about $4.3 billion (footnote 6). 
 
8. 
Joint-Stock Banks. Unlike the SOCBs, a number of the JSBs have performed well and 
are quite profitable. The JSBs have achieved average returns on equity (ROEs) of between 15 
and 30%, and NPLs are estimated to be substantially lower than those of the SOCBs. At less 
than 15 years old the JSBs are young, and can be divided into three groups: (i) the top five large 
urban  banks,  (ii)  a  smaller  group  of  about  19  banks  that  are  either  growing  rapidly  or  have 
established a niche, and (iii) 12 small rural JSBs. The top five urban banks are Techcombank, 
Sacombank,  Vietnam  International  Bank,  Asia  Commercial  Bank,  and  East  Asia  Commercial 
Bank.  The  smaller  urban  JSB  group  consists  of  banks  such  as  Habu  Bank,  Viet  A  Bank,  and 
Saigon  Bank.  Most  of  the  top  five  JSBs  have  large  international  strategic  investors,  such  as 
HSBC,  Australia  &  New  Zealand  Banking  Group  Ltd.  (ANZ),  and  Standard  Chartered.  These 
investors  recognize  the  large  growth  potential  and  profitability  of  the  JSBs,  and  are  also 
assisting the JSBs meet capital adequacy ratio requirements. 
 
Growth Opportunities. The potential for growth in the banking sector is high as banking 
9. 
services  are  underutilized  in  Viet  Nam.  Penetration  levels  are  quite  low,  with  less  than  5%  of 
Viet  Nam’s  total  population  of  80  million  using  banking  services  on  a  regular  basis,  and  less 
than 20% having bank accounts (footnote 1). In order to capitalize on the high growth potential 
and to prepare for a more competitive environment, banks must (i) expand their product lines, (ii) 
implement  better  corporate  governance,  and  (iii)  increase  their  market  penetration.  These 
actions  are  particularly  important  for  the  JSBs,  many  of  which  are  following  a  strategy  of 
concurrently  expanding  their  retail  banking  services  and  their  SME  lending.  In  general, 
consolidations of the major banks are not expected in the short term because these banks have 
great  opportunities  to  grow  in  this  rapidly  expanding  market.  However,  in  the  medium  to  long 
term, as foreign competition increases, the sector may experience increasing consolidation.  
 
The  retail  market  in  Viet  Nam  is  in  its  nascent  stages.  Only  2  million  individuals  have 
10. 
automatic teller machine (ATM) cards, and the ratio of cash payments to bank transfers is high 
at  22.8%  (footnote  1).  VinaCapital,  a  large  investment  banking  and  fund  manager,  projects 
growth  rates  of  about  33%  for  bank  accounts  and  around  31%  for  debit  and  credit  cards 
(footnote  1).  JSBs,  in  particular,  have  been  limited  in  their  ability  to  build  multiple  consumer-
lending product lines such as mortgages, vehicle loans, and credit or debit cards. To modernize 
the banking sector and provide the multitude of services demanded by the population (both now 
and increasingly in the future), banks need access to long-term funding now. As one investment 
banker stated: “For the smarter banks, it’s a case of retail or fail” (footnote 1). 
 
 
 

                                                 
12  Fitch  Ratings.  2007.  Fitch  Upgrades  the  Ratings  of  Vietnam’s  State-Owned  Commercial  Banks.  Hong  Kong  (2 

May). 

 

 4 

 

 

 

C. 

The Housing and Mortgage Market in Viet Nam 

1. 

Housing Supply and Demand 

Supply.  Viet  Nam’s  urban  centers  have  been  growing  since  the  mid-1990s.  As  the 
11. 
country  has  shifted  to  a  market  economy  and  new  manufacturing  industries  have  been 
established near major cities, urbanization rates have steadily increased. Experts indicate that 
the population of urban centers will grow at a rate of slightly over 1 million per year.13 At this rate, 
Viet  Nam  will  have  one  of  the  highest  population  densities  in  Asia.  However,  despite  the 
country’s  current  economic  achievements,  residential  housing  in  urban  areas  remains 
underdeveloped.  
 
Housing  stock  levels  have  lagged  behind  demand  for  a  variety  of  reasons.  The  state-
12. 
subsidized housing system, followed by state-sponsored construction companies, did not have 
access  to  a  steady  supply  of  funds  to  build  residential  housing  in  urban  areas.  As  a  result, 
residential  housing  was  constructed  on  a  sporadic  basis.  A  market-oriented  model  of  housing 
construction  began  to  evolve  in  the  mid-1990s,  as  some  privately  owned  businesses  were 
allowed  to  produce  a  few  houses.  Most  construction  was  funded  through  informal,  nonbank 
processes, with capital coming from overseas remittances, savings accumulated by households, 
or  from  borrowings  from  friends,  relatives,  or  families;  bank  loans  were  nonexistent.  Thus, 
private housing construction was undertaken primarily by the wealthy classes.  
 
13. 
In the past few years, however, housing construction has diversified to include a wider 
variety  of  market  segments.  Most  developers  have  targeted  the  upper  class  and  expatriate 
markets, but condominiums for middle-class families have been constructed within the last few 
years. Many of the condominiums did not sell, and this was due to the unavailability of mortgage 
financing. Although the landscape for urban housing has diversified, the Government maintains 
control  of  the  overall  pace  of  property  developments  in  larger  cities.  The  Government  has 
indicated that large property developments must be developed in a comprehensive manner that 
includes  infrastructure  such  as  schools  and  roads.  There  is  an  increased  emphasis  by  the 
Government  that  housing  construction  needs  to  be  further  diversified  to  include  lower  and 
middle income classes.   
 
14. 
Viet Nam’s accession into the WTO is expected to bolster the supply of urban housing 
for  a  broader  market  segment.  The  Land  Law  of  2003,  Law  on  Housing  of  2005,  Law  on 
Residence  of  2006  and  the  Real  Estate  Trading  Law  of  January  2007  have  eased  the 
restrictions on the market for developers. Foreign developers are no longer required to establish 
a  joint  venture  with  local  partners.  The  Real  Estate  Trading  Law  strengthens  the  property 
market by addressing such issues as illicit transactions and speculation, and this will contribute 
to  a  healthier  market.  Additional  property  developments  are  anticipated  with  the  entrance  of 
world-class  companies.  Foreign  developers  have  already  started  construction  on  a  number  of 
units in the larger cities. Ayala Land from the Philippines and Keppel Land of Singapore have 
entered the market, as have developers from Korea, Japan, and Indonesia. The Government is 
hopeful  that  development  costs  will  be  dictated  by  a  more  competitive  market,  which  will  then 
broaden access to different levels of housing for the middle and lower classes.  
 
15. 
Housing Demand. A number of sources indicate increased demand for urban housing. 
Table 1 provides the Government’s estimates for housing demand in urban areas. Real estate 

                                                 
13 ADB and Cities Alliance. 2006. Urbanization and Sustainability in Asia:  Case Studies  of Good Practices. Manila 

(November, Chapter 14: Vietnam, page 375). 

 developers  project  that  demand  will  grow  at  a  rate  of  6–7%  per  year. 14   In  some  cities, 
particularly  Hanoi,  demand  is  estimated  to  continue  to  outpace  supply  (Figure  1).  Several 
changes in Viet Nam have led to an increase in the demand. As the economy has improved and 
incomes  have  increased,  young  professionals  are  seeking  to  move  out  of  their  family  homes 
and  purchase  a  condominium  in  urban  areas  or  small  houses  outside  of  the  major  cities. 
Average per capita income levels are growing steadily. In 2005, the average per capita income 
was $636. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects that it will be $715 in 2006 and $793 
in  2007.  ADB’s  CSP  (2007–2010)  projects  an  average  per  capita  income  of  $1,050–1,100  by 
2010.  Real  incomes  are  often  difficult  to  measure  in  Viet  Nam  as  typically  there  are  multiple 
sources  of  income  for  a  family,  including  official  employment,  small-business  income,  and 
overseas remittances. Last year, Viet Nam had overseas remittances of over $4 billion.15

16. 
Housing Prices. Housing prices in urban areas of Viet Nam have increased in the past 
2–3  years.  Price  escalation  has  been  primarily  due  to  demand  exceeding  supply  and  to 
speculation. Given the very limited size of the stock market, investors have perceived property 
investments  as  safe  and  easy.  As  supply  grows  and  the  number  of  companies  and  financial 
institutions on the stock market increases with the forthcoming equitizations, it is anticipated that 
property prices will stabilize in certain market segments. High-end property prices are currently 
stable and are expected to increase somewhat more in some urban areas. However, prices for

continue to do so over the medium term.16
 

2. 

Mortgage Lending 

17. 
At  the  core  of  the  development  of  these  large  urban  areas  is  access  to  adequate  and 
affordable housing, and this is facilitated by (i) a healthy property market with adequate supply 
and  rational  pricing,  and  (ii)  long-term  mortgage  financing.  As  discussed,  housing  supply  is 
starting to grow in Viet Nam and property prices in the middle to low-end segments have started 
to stabilize and are now decreasing. Viet Nam, however, has a limited mortgage finance market. 
Various  sources  have  estimated  that  mortgages  account  for  only  3%  of  the  total  outstanding 
loans in the banking sector.17
 
18. 
The  market  has  been  constrained  for  a  number  of  reasons.  Affordability  has  been  a 
major issue, and there is very limited long-term financing available to the banks. Thus, although 
the banks noted above indicate that they will lend on longer terms, typically they will not due to a 
lack of long-term funding. Therefore, tenors on mortgage loans typically range from 3 to 5 years. 
Given that monthly payments increase as the tenor of the loan decreases, mortgages have not 
been  an  option  for  most  people  (Appendix  3  gives  an  example  of  the  impact  of  longer-term 
mortgages on monthly payments). Mortgage lending has also been limited because of the legal 
and regulatory framework surrounding this market.  
 
19. 
The  regulatory  and  legal  framework  for  mortgage  lending  has  improved  substantially 
over the last year. In the past both ADB and the International Finance Corporation (IFC) have 
provided  technical  assistance  to  the  Government  pertaining  to  the  legal  and  regulatory 
framework  for  mortgage  lending.  In  July  2006,  the  Government  introduced  a  new  law  on 
housing,  the  first  to  put  forward  a  more  comprehensive  legal  framework  for  ownership,  lease, 
use,  and  management  of  houses,  including  apartments,  by  local  and  foreign  individuals  and 
organizations.  In  December  2006,  the  Government  published  implementing  regulations  that 
clarified  some  outstanding  issues  pertaining  to  the  housing  market.  The  Ministry  of  Natural 
Resources  and  Environment  (MONRE)  has  standardized  and  shortened  procedures  for  land 
use  rights  certificates  (LURC)  issuance.  MONRE  has  also  established  the  Land  Title  Office 
under  the  Department  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  to  deal  with  LUCR  issuance, 
transfer of land use rights, and secured transaction registration related to land use rights. The 
Government  has  also  taken  measures  to  improve  the  property  registration  system,  setting  a 
target of having all properties registered by the end of 2007. In January 2007, the prime minister 
approved a large project to upgrade the registration system by the creation of a database that 
will be accessed by banks and will contain all registered properties. The project is planned to be 
fully  implemented  within  2  years.  With  respect  to  foreclosing  property,  nonjudicial  and  judicial 
foreclosure  is  permitted  under  Vietnamese  law.  Nonjudicial  foreclosure  can  be  pursued  if  this 
concept is included in the mortgage contract; it can take 1 to 3 years to complete the foreclosure 
through the judicial process. Appendix 4 has additional information on the legal and regulatory 
framework for housing finance in Viet Nam.

A. 

Background 

III. 

THE BORROWER 

Techcombank was registered as a JSB in 1993. It is currently the ninth largest bank in 
20. 
Viet Nam and the fourth largest JSB as measured by its assets and shareholder equity.18  The 
bank  was  established  to  become  an  efficient  private  sector  financial  intermediary  between 
savers and businesses in need of capital in the era of market liberalization in Viet Nam.  
 
21. 
Techcombank currently offers a wide range of traditional banking services, including (i) 
mobilizing  and  receiving  short-term,  medium-term,  and  long-term  capital  from  companies  and 
individuals;  (ii)  lending  short-term,  medium-term,  and  long-term  capital  to  organizations  and 
individuals;  (iii)  conducting  foreign  currency  transactions;  (iv)  providing  transaction  services 
between customers; and (v) other banking services as approved by the SBV. The milestones of 
Techcombank’s development since 1993 are described in Appendix 5.  
 
B. 

Credit Rating 

22. 
In  September  2006,  Techcombank  became  the  first  JSB  in  Viet  Nam  to  obtain  credit 
ratings from Moody’s rating agency. The bank received a Ba2 for long- and short-term foreign 
currency issuer ratings, Ba1 for long- and short-term local currency issuer ratings, and a Bank 
Financial  Strength  Rating  (BFSR)  of  D–.  The  outlook  for  all  the  deposit  and  issuer  ratings  is 
assessed “stable” and the outlook for the BFSR is rated “positive”.  
 
C. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

23. 
Techcombank’s  primary  business  consists  of  retail  and  corporate  banking.  Its  retail 
banking  activities  include  lending  and  deposit  taking,  as  well  as  providing  payment  cards, 
consumer  loans,  and  mortgages.  Its  corporate  banking  division  provides  a  broad  range  of 
banking  products  to  a  diversified  group  of  domestic  customers,  primarily  SMEs.  The  bank  is 
also  an  active  participant  in  the  fixed  income  securities  and  foreign  currency  markets  in  Viet 
Nam.  
 

1. 

Business Lines 

a. 

Retail Banking 

24. 
Focused  Products.  Retail  banking  is  a  core  business  of  Techcombank.  Historically  it 
has  been  a  small  portion  of  the  bank’s  business  but  it  is  now  becoming  the  bank’s  dominant 
product  line.  The  bank’s  strategy  for  retail  banking  is  to  provide  a  full  range  of  products  and 
services  to  meet  the  particular  needs  of  the  customers  at  various  stages  in  their  life.  These 
services  include  demand  deposit  accounts,  savings,  loans,  payments,  credit  and  debit  cards, 
investments, guarantees, and safe custody facilities.  
 
Expansion in Retail Business. Retail business is the bank’s key growth segment and it 
25. 
intends  to  further  increase  retail  loans  as  a  proportion  of  its  total  loan  book.  Techcombank’s 
retail  business  is  expanding  rapidly  as  it  benefits  from  fast  economic  growth  and  the  ensuing 
increase  in  per-capita  income  and  changing  consumer  habits.  By  the  end  of  2006,  the  bank 
served individual clients at 73 locations in 15 cities and provinces nationwide.

26.  Mortgage  Lending.  Mortgage  lending  at  Techcombank  has  been  growing,  but  is  still 
small  as  an  overall  percentage  of  its  lending  activities  when  compared  with  banks  in  more 
developed  markets.  The  bank  has  been  limited  by  a  lack  of  long-term  funds.  With  access  to 
longer-term  financing,  Techcombank  estimates that  it  can  double  its  mortgage  portfolio  by  the 
end  of  2007.  The  bank  had  approximately  4,500  mortgage  loans  with  an  average  size  of 
$26,000 at the end of 2006, and the age of its mortgage portfolio is quite young (about 5 years 
old). The maximum loan-to-value ratio (LTV) at which the bank currently lends is 70%, with the 
average being somewhat lower. Techcombank can offer 15-year loans, but the average tenor is 
generally about 5 years, and loans primarily have a floating rate basis. The bank has been able 
to successfully foreclose a property. 
 
27. 
Techcombank  has  developed  several  products  aimed  specifically  at  market  segments, 
including  (i)  the  New  Home  program  aimed  at  the  middle  and  upper  classes,  (ii)  the  Young 
Family  program  which  targets  young  professionals  at  medium  income  levels,  and  (iii)  the 
Affordable  Housing  program  which  focuses  on  lower  income  groups.  The  Affordable  Housing 
program  is  supported,  in  part,  by  ADB’s  public  sector  Housing  Finance  Project  Loan  1990. 
Techcombank is in the process of developing mortgage products with a tenor of 20 years that 
will serve to broaden its penetration in this market and provide more affordable housing.  
 

b. 

Corporate Banking 

Techcombank’s  corporate  and  commercial  banking  business  includes  deposit  taking, 
28. 
business loans with a focus on SMEs, international settlements, and trade finance. Although the 
number of business clients increased by over 30% in 2006, and lending to them increased by 
more than 50% over the previous year, Techcombank’s key growth area is retail banking. 
 

2. 

Trade Finance and Remittances 

29. 
Trade  Finance.  Techcombank  has  the  largest  trade  finance  market  share  amongst  all 
JSBs in Viet Nam, and has a network of relationships with over 400 banks in over 100 countries 
worldwide.  Techcombank’s  network  is  particularly  well  positioned  in  the  People’s  Republic  of 
China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea, which are important markets for Vietnamese SMEs.  

  
30. 
ADB  has  a  trade  finance  facility  valued  at  $6  million  in  place  with  Techcombank,  and 
disbursed from it to Techcombank twice in 2005. Each disbursement was valued at $3 million 
carrying  a  tenor  of  6  months,  and  both  loans  were  repaid  on  time.  ADB  is  in  the  process  of 
disbursing another $3 million under the facility. 
 
31. 
Remittances.  Techcombank  is  also  active  in  providing  remittance  services.  The  bank 
plans  to  increase  its  remittance  business  by  creating  more  links  with  remittance  companies  in 
the Middle East and South America. 
 

IV. 

THE PROPOSED LOAN 

A. 

ADB Loan 

32. 
The loan may be funded in dong or US dollars in an amount of up to $25 million. Dong 
funding may be made available through a cross-currency swap, subject to all relevant approvals 
having  been  obtained.  ADB’s  Treasury  Department  has  received  verbal  indications  from  the 
Government that the cross-currency swap will be approved. 
 
B. 

Main Terms and Conditions 

1. 

 
The loan will be sourced from ADB’s ordinary capital resources and the interest 
rate will be determined by ADB’s Pricing and Credit Enhancement Committee. If ADB is unable 
to  provide  funding  in  local  currency,  the  loan  will  be  offered  in  US  dollars.  The  committee  will 
also  determine  the  up-front  and  commitment  fees.  Subject  to  further  advice  from  Vietnamese 
counsel, the loan may be secured through a pledge of the underlying mortgage loan receivables 
funded with ADB’s loan. 
 

V. 

INVESTMENT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Justification 

1. 

Development Outcome 

33. 
 

(i) 

The proposed ADB assistance will promote the following development. 

Strengthening  the  banking  sector.  As  discussed,  the  banking  sector  in  Viet 
Nam  is  weak  and  has  been  targeted  as  a  priority  sector  for  ADB  support.  The 
proposed ADB assistance will be an integral part of the strategy for strengthening 
Viet Nam’s banking sector through the support of a dynamic and well-managed 
JSB.  Banking  sectors  greatly  benefit  from  the  ability  to  undertake  mortgage 
financing. Long-term mortgages can reduce funding and liquidity risks in banks. 
Mortgage  financing  also  encourages  the  growth  and  diversification  of  the 
financial  services  sector,  which  many  studies  have  shown  to  be  a  key  factor  in 
economic  development.  Mortgages  are  often  a  bank’s  highest  quality  asset,  as 
default rates are typically lower than other asset classes; people are less likely to 
default  on  their  mortgage  than  on  a  car  loan  or  a  credit  card  debt.  When 
affordable  housing  can  be  accessed,  consumers  begin  to  save  for  down-
payments  and  loan  repayments.  These  actions  increase  both  the  assets 
available  to  the  financial  services  sector  and  the  demand  for  more  financial 
services.  The  introduction  or  expansion  of  private-sector  mortgage  lending 

 

 

 10 

 

 

 

 
(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

strengthens  a  country’s  financial  sector  through  the  addition  of  new  banking 
products  and  services  and  the  diversification  of  risks  across  a  broadened 
portfolio. 

Meet demand for urban housing and support the development of a primary 
mortgage market. As discussed, demand for housing in urban areas has grown 
concurrently with the improvement of the economy and the subsequent increase 
in  income  levels.  Access  to  housing  has  been  impeded  due  to  a  very  small 
formal  mortgage  market.  Through  ADB’s  proposed  loan  to  Techcombank,  the 
urban population will have broader access to housing through mortgage lending. 
Long-term  funding  in  local  currency  provided  by  ADB  will  enable  Techcombank 
to  increase  the  tenor  of  its  mortgage  loans,  which  will  decrease  monthly 
payments  and  therefore  result  in  improved  affordability.  Additionally,  as  banks 
gain  experience  in  the  mortgage  product  and  credit  assessment  of  individual 
borrowers,  they  will  be  better  able  to  offer  mortgage  products  to  good  quality 
borrowers in wider income brackets.  

found  within  economies 

Job creation and revenue generation. The development of a primary mortgage 
market is essential for a country’s socioeconomic growth. At its most basic level, 
mortgage  financing  provides  access  to  shelter  or  improvements  to  existing 
housing. The creation of a primary  mortgage market can significantly contribute 
to  job  creation  and  revenue  generation  in  a  country.  Strong  backward  linkages 
are  often 
through  primary  mortgage  markets. 
Employment  related  to  the  construction  and  home  improvement  industries  is 
supported  and  jobs  in  the  real  estate  sector,  such  as  with  appraisal  companies 
and  land  titling  or  registration  services,  are  created.  The  purchase  of  consumer 
goods also increases, particularly as a family begins to furnish its first home with 
new  appliances  and  furniture.  It  is  estimated  that  approximately  15%  of  a 
country’s total workforce can be generated by mortgage financing.19 With respect 
to forward links, mortgage lending can serve as a vehicle by creating one of the 
most  important  sources  of  capital  for  an  individual  or  family.  Capital  for  the 
establishment of SMEs can be accessed through a mortgaged property. Finally, 
governments benefit from taxation on the properties and businesses.  

Catalyzing  capital  markets.  Broadening  and  deepening  a  country’s  capital 
markets  is  important  to  its  overall  economic  development.  The  creation  of  a 
secondary mortgage market can catalyze capital-market development. However, 
a  well-functioning  secondary  mortgage  market  cannot  be  developed  without  a 
strong  primary  mortgage  market.  A  primary  mortgage  market  must  be  able  to 
produce  a  large  volume  of  good  quality  mortgages  that  have  been  originated 
according  to  standardized  documentation.  In  order  to  produce  good  quality 
mortgages,  solid  and  consistent  underwriting  must  be  undertaken  by  banks. 
Once the mortgages have been originated, servicing of the loans and tracking of 
performance must be undertaken. All of these functions contribute to an efficient 
secondary  mortgage  market.  Support  of  the  establishment  of  a  strong  primary 
mortgage market will hasten the pace of capital-market development.

2. 

Investment Objectives 

34. 
ADB’s  objectives  for  the  proposed  loan  are  (i)  to  increase  the  availability  of  long-term 
mortgage financing, thereby contributing to the provision of more affordable housing; and (ii) to 
strengthen  the  financial  sector  by  enabling  a  strong  JSB  to  increase  its  activities  in  the  retail 
banking sector.  
 
3. 

Project Outcome 

The expected outcome of the proposed loan is that Techcombank will be able to provide 

35. 
increased access to long-term mortgage loans to individuals in Viet Nam. 

 
4. 

Value Added by ADB 

36. 
The  proposed  loan  will  enable  Techcombank  to  meet  its  core  objective  of  building  a 
mortgage loan portfolio, while contributing to the overall growth of its retail business. The long-
term  financing  that  ADB  will  provide  is  critical  for  the  growth  of  the  mortgage  business  in  Viet 
Nam.  Long-term  financing  is  needed  to  enable  the  bank  to  lend  on  longer  terms,  which  will 
improve the affordability of mortgages for consumers. ADB will require Techcombank to adhere 
to internationally prudent LTV ratios, which will ensure good credit underwriting standards and 
reduce  systematic  risks  in  the  market. 20   In  addition,  Techcombank’s  portfolio  will  be 
strengthened by the addition of high-quality assets. More broadly, ADB will build upon its current 
relationship with Techcombank, and in doing so, will encourage the adoption of better practices 
and  anti-money 
laundering,  anti-corruption,  and  environmental  safeguard  policies  and 
procedures. 
 

5. 

Design and Monitoring Framework 

ADB  has  prepared  a  design  and  monitoring  framework  and  will  measure  the  expected 
37. 
development  impact  of  the  loan  in  accordance with  ADB’s  Management  Development  Results 
Policy.21 (The design and monitoring framework appears in Appendix 15). 
 
B. 

Social and Environmental Safeguard Policies 

38. 
The loan has been assigned a category FI environmental classification and is classified 
as  category  C  with  respect  to  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous  Peoples  (1998)  and  Involuntary 
Resettlement  Policy  (1995).  Techcombank  has  procedures  in  place  to  identify  environmental 
risks  as  required  by  the  trade  finance  agreement  with  ADB.  Techcombank  will  be  required  to 
maintain an environmental management system following the guidelines in Appendix 16 and to 
build capacity for implementing it. At least one Techcombank officer will attend ADB-sponsored 
environmental management training.

C. 

Anticorruption  Policy:  Combating  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of 
Terrorism 

39. 
ADB has undertaken due diligence on Techcombank’s procedures in respect of money 
laundering and financing of terrorism. Techcombank was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
(1998,  as  amended  to  date)  and  policy  relating  to  Combating  of  Money  Laundering  and  the 
Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003). 22   Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  ADB  will  require  Techcombank  to  institute,  maintain,  and 
comply with internal procedures and controls following international best practice standards for 
the purpose of preventing corruption or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism 
in  the  reimbursement  and  indemnity  agreements.  Further,  Techcombank  will  undertake  to 
refrain  from  engaging  in  such  activities.  The  documentation  between  ADB  and  Techcombank 
will further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings.  
 

VI. 

ASSURANCES 

ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  finance  documentation  following  approval  of  the  proposed 

40. 
financing by ADB’s Board of Directors, on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB. 
 
41. 
Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  the 
Government of Viet Nam will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
loan to Techcombank. The loan will not be disbursed until ADB receives such confirmation. 
 

VII.  RECOMMENDATION 

42. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Article  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve the loan of up to $25,000,000 (to be funded in local currency or US dollars) to Vietnam 
Technological  and  Commercial  Joint-stock  Bank  (Techcombank)  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources, with interest to be determined based on the procedures applicable to nonsovereign 
loans  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set 
forth in this report and as may be reported to the Board.

VIET NAM: MAJOR MACROECONOMIC CONSIDERATIONS 

Economic Outlook 

 
A. 
 
Viet Nam has made significant gains in improving its economy and alleviating poverty. It 
1. 
was  the  second  fastest  growing  economy  in  Asia  with  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth 
rates  between  7.0%  and  almost  8.5%  during  the  period  from  2003  to  June  2006, 1  and  it  is 
expected to be about 8.2% for 2006.2  
 
2. 
Gross  Domestic  Product.  The  country’s  five-year  plan  for  2006–2010  targets  GDP 
growth at 7.5–8.0%. Viet Nam benefits from a number of factors that are likely to sustain a high 
growth rate. The country has a rapidly growing workforce, with more than half of the workforce 
under 25 years old and about 30% of the population under 15 years old. Literacy rates of the 
workforce are high at 93%,3  and there are strong opportunities for growth in the manufacturing 
sector  on  this  basis;  Canon  and  Intel  corporations  have  stated  that  they  will  be  establishing 
plants in Viet Nam. Another growth factor is that individual savings rates are high. In 1990, the 
savings  rate  was  about  5%;  by  2005  it  had  increased  to  36%. 4   High  savings  levels  have 
paralleled the growth in investment rates. Additionally, the macroeconomic policy framework is 
supportive of continued high growth rates. 
  
Fiscal Performance. In the period from 2001 to 2006, the budget balance improved. Oil 
3. 
revenues  contributed  strongly  to  the  growth  of  revenues,  comprising  8–10%  of  GDP,  which  is 
about 33% of total government revenues (footnote 4). Also contributing to revenue growth has 
been  the  expansion  of  the  tax  base  and  improved  tax  administration.  However,  to  further 
strengthen  the  current  tax  base,  the  tax  system  will  need  to  be  expanded  to  individuals  and 
private  enterprises,  as  the  Government  has  traditionally  relied  upon  taxes  from  state-owned 
enterprises  (SOEs).  While  the  Government’s  fiscal  performance  is  strong  and  revenues  are 
projected to remain at healthy levels, there will be some pressure in the next few years. One of

Plan. The funds are disbursed through the Vietnam Development Bank (VDB) and are typically 
used  for  infrastructure  financing.  These  funds  are  generally  provided  by  official  development

Monetary  Developments.  Decision  112  that  was  issued  in  May  2006  by  the 
5. 
Vietnamese Government was formulated to convert the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) into a fully 
independent  central  bank  responsible  for  monetary  policy  and  supervision  of  financial 
institutions. The SBV will divest its shareholdings in the state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) 
and will have a mandate to (i) protect the value of the currency, (ii) control inflation, (iii) ensure 
the  safety  of  the  monetary  and  banking  system,  and  (iv)  create  a  favorable  macroeconomic 
environment  for  growth  and  development.  The  SBV  is  expected  to  maintain  a  careful,  but 
flexible, monetary policy direction, with the main policy target being to keep the annual inflation 
rate below 7%.  
 
6. 
External  Developments.  At  about  37%  of  GDP  for  2005,  current  government  debt 
levels are low.6 The majority of the country’s debt consists of low interest rate loans from official 
donor agencies. The IMF anticipates that debt will increase gradually over the medium term and 
peak by 2009 at 42.5% of GDP. The increase will be primarily due to state-sector restructuring. 
The  IMF  has  also  highlighted  banking  sector  contingent  liabilities  as  an  area  of  concern. 
Nonperforming  loans  (NPLs)  are  estimated  at  about  15%  of  GDP.  Viet  Nam’s  vulnerability  to 
external shocks that would impact debt repayments is low, given that most debt is from official 
donor agencies. Overall vulnerability to external shock is mitigated by a current account that has 
remained  in  surplus  due  to  high  levels  of  remittances,  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI),  and 
growing tourism receipts. As a result, foreign exchange reserves were $9.2 billion at the end of 
2005.7
 
7. 
Continued  growth  is  dependent  upon  successful  execution  of  a  number  of  planned 
government  reforms.  The  Government  has  committed  to  transitioning  to  a  market  economy 
within  the  next  5  years.  Its  strategy  is  based  on  the  equitization  of  state-owned  enterprises 
(SOEs)  and  SOCBs.  Additionally,  the  Government  has  targeted  the  strengthening  of  the 
broader banking sector (including joint-stock banks), the development of private capital markets, 
and infrastructure-related investments, as critical to this transition. Accession to the World Trade 
Organization (WTO) in January 2007 marked decades of economic transformation for Viet Nam, 
and  it  is  likely  that  WTO  membership  will  stimulate  more  growth.  Reforms  undertaken  for  the 
process  of  the  country’s  accession  to  the  WTO  will  not  be  reversed.  While  there  is  a  risk that 
implementation of these reforms could be slow, the current political environment is supportive of 
them.  
 
8. 
Exchange  Rate. The Government strictly regulates the dong. Since January 2007 with 
the  country’s  accession  to  the  WTO,  the  SBV  has  widened  the  daily  fluctuation  limits  of  the 
dong against the US dollar from plus or minus 0.25% to plus or minus 0.5% in order to maintain 
a more flexible exchange rate policy. The dong has been depreciating marginally against the US 
dollar  to  maintain  competitiveness  in  the  export  sector.  With  the  recent  increase  of  portfolio 
investment capital inflows into the financial market, the dong is starting to appreciate.

Political Outlook 

B. 
 
9. 
The  Communist  Party  of  Vietnam  (CPV),  led  by  Party  General  Secretary  Nong  Duc 
Manh,  is  the  leading  entity,  with  power  over  state  and  societal  matters  in  Viet  Nam.  Party 
General Secretary Nong Duc Manh was reelected in April 2006, which is a positive indication for 
continued reforms. He is considered to be quite supportive of reforms within the country and as 
one  of  his  primary  goals  has  targeted  2020  as  the  year  by  which  Viet  Nam  will  become 
industrialized.  Within  the  CPV  there  is  some  moderate  internal  division  between  more 
conservative  members,  who  have  been  ambivalent  to  economic  liberalization,  and  reform-
minded individuals. However, with the appointment of Nong Duc Manh as general secretary, it is 
unlikely  that  conservative  elements  will  emerge  with  more  strength.  The  CPV  has  a  strong 
presence within the Quoc-Hoi (the National Assembly), comprising 90% of the current assembly.  
 
10. 
President Nguyen Minh Triet is head of state and he appointed Prime Minister Nguyen 
Tan Dung, who is considered to be an economic reformer. He was previously head of the SBV 
and then deputy prime minister. President Triet has a history of combating corruption and has 
increasingly  emphasized  this  issue  within  the  Government.  There  has  been  some  moderate 
shift in the overlap between the CPV and the Government, with the top three state leaders no 
longer  attending  Politburo  meetings.  In  practice,  daily  leadership  of  the  country  is  shared 
between the general secretary of the CPV, the prime minister, and the president.

 18 

Appendix 3 

LEGAL AND REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR PROPERTY AND MORTGAGES 
 

1. 
The  regulatory  and  legal  framework  in  Viet  Nam  for  mortgage  lending  has  improved 
substantially in the last few years. In December 2003, the Government introduced the Land Law 
and Decree 181/2004 (the Land Law). The National Assembly also passed the Housing Law in 
November  2005,  which  became  effective  in  July  2006.  The  Housing  Law  sets  out  a  more 
comprehensive  legal  framework  for  ownership,  lease,  use,  and  management  of  houses 
(including  apartments)  by  local  and  foreign  individuals  and  organizations.  In  December  2006, 
the  Government  published  implementing  regulations  (Decree  95)  that  clarified  the  housing 
certificate registration and ownership right of building.  
 
2. 
Land  Use  Rights.  Property in Viet Nam is designated as either freehold or leasehold. 
Leasehold  property  belongs  to  various  branches  of  the  Government  and  commercial  entities. 
Due to historical reasons, government agencies and state-owned enterprises (SOEs) occupy a 
significant amount of land; private-sector access to land for both commercial and residential use 
is  somewhat  limited.  Freehold  property,  on  the  other  hand,  belongs  to  the  people.  In  order  to 
build a house or to buy an existing house, an individual must obtain a land use right certificate 
(LURC).  The  Land  Law  provides  the  legal  framework  for  registration  and  issuance  of  LURCs. 
Under the Land Law, the land management agency (referred as to the Land Registration Office) 
is responsible for processing and issuance of LURCs. The Land Registration Office is organized 
vertically from the central to the grassroots levels to facilitate a national uniform land use right 
registration system.  
 
3. 
First time issuance of LURCs is important for the development of the formal property and 
mortgage  finance  market.  Some  statistics  indicate  that  less  than  50%  of  land  has  been 
registered  in  larger  urban  cities.  In  the  past,  the  issuance  process  for  first  time  LURCs  was 
inefficient  and  lengthy.  The  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  (MONRE)  has 
standardized and shortened procedures for LURC issuance, and has established the Land Title 
Office  under  the  Department  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  to  manage  the  LURC 
process, transfer of land use rights, and secured transaction registration related to land use right. 
The new LURC process eliminates some previously needed steps, such as securing approvals 
from the chairman of the People’s Committee. Figure A4 shows the steps for LURC issuance.

Appendix 3 

19

Mortgage  Registration.  The  fundamental  laws  governing  the  mortgaging  of  land  use 
4. 
rights and buildings including houses and other immovable structures fixed to land are set forth 
in  the  2005  Land  Law  and  the  Civil  Code.  These  provisions  are  further  defined  in  the  Decree 
163,  circulars  05  and  03  on  secured  transactions.  Under  the  current  regulations,  the  Land 
Registration  Office  is  responsible  for  registration  of  secured  transactions  related  to  land,  any 
existing assets on land, and any assets on land to be formed. 
 
5. 
Improvements  have  been  introduced  to  the  mortgage  registration  process,  and  these 
have shortened the time taken for registration. Within 5 days of signing a mortgage contract, the 
mortgage  must  be  registered  by  either  the  mortgagor  or  mortgagee.  The  dossier  submitted  to 
the  Land  Registration  Office  at  the  district  level  includes  (i)  an  application  form  for  mortgage 
registration,  (ii)  an  LURC,  (iii)  a  right  certificate  of  the  building  on  land,  and  (iv)  a  building 
construction  permit.  The  timeline  for  the  Land  Registration  Office  to  complete  the  mortgage 
registration has been shortened from 5 days (Circular 05 dated 16 June 2005) to one working 
day  (Circular  03  as  of  13  June  2006).  The  fee for  mortgage  registration  is  D50,000  (over  $3). 
The  Land  Registration  Office  also  has  to  send  a  monthly  report  on  all  registered  mortgage 
transactions  to  the  Secure  Transaction  Registry  Agency  under  the  Ministry  of  Justice  for 
consolidation.  
 
6. 
A great number of real estate transactions were conducted informally in the past. In an 
effort to improve the property registration system, in January 2007 the Government approved a 
$50 million project to modernize the land administration system. It has set a target of having all 
residential properties registered by the end of 2007. A database is expected to be established to 
store  both  land  registration  and  mortgage  registration  information,  and  this  will  then  be 
accessed by commercial banks. In future, when an individual applies for a mortgage, the bank 
will be able to immediately access the land registry. The project is expected to be funded by the 
World Bank and the Government of Sweden.  
 
Another requirement of the mortgage registration process is notarization. Notaries must 
7. 
certify  the  validity  and  legality  of  each  mortgage  contract.  Most  notaries  are  reluctant  to  sign 
bank forms and would rather use their own standard forms. This requirement complicates and 
lengthens the process of mortgage registration.  
 
8. 
Foreclosure.  In  the  past  asset  foreclosure  in  Viet  Nam  was  regulated  by  the  Inter-
ministerial  Circular  03/2001  on  Handling  the  Loan  Security  Asset  to  Recover  Debts  of  Credit 
Institutions. The circular outlined the instructions to local authorities and the police on how and 
in  what  circumstances  they  should  proceed  to  recover  mortgaged  property.  It  also  required  a 
mortgagee  to  obtain  the  permission  of  the  relevant  people’s  committee  before  auctioning 
property.  This  law  was  considered  to  be  unclear  and  cumbersome  by  those  undertaking  the 
foreclosure process.  
 
9. 
Asset  foreclosure  laws  have  also  been  recently  strengthened.  However,  overlapping 
laws  still  govern  the  process  and  there  remain  some  vague  areas  that  could  be  further 
improved.  In  2006,  the  Government  introduced  Decree  163  on  secured  transactions.  In 
conjunction  with  the  Land  Law,  Decree  163  implements  the  new  framework  for  secured 
transactions  that  was  introduced  by  the  Civil  Code  and  is  considered  to  improve  and  clarify 
previous  regulations  governing  foreclosure.  Both  judicial  and  nonjudicial  foreclosures  are 
currently  allowed.  Both  methods  of  foreclosure  have  recourse  through  the  laws  for  seizure  of 
property with police action if there is resistance. 

 
 

 

 20 

Appendix 3 

In  order  to  pursue  the  more  preferable  nonjudicial  foreclosure  process,  the  steps  to 
10. 
foreclosure must be agreed upon and contained in the mortgage contract. Options for property 
disposal  must  also  be  included  in  the  contract.  Decree  163  gives  some  guidance  on  the 
methods by which the property can be disposed of. Some of these options include (i) a sale with 
the proceeds being remitted to the lender, (ii) outright ownership of the property, and (iii) receipt 
of another property of equivalent market value. Auctions can also be undertaken as a method 
for property disposal. It is important to note that both private and state auctions can be used in 
the foreclosure process; state auctions will often yield lower prices on the property. 
 
11.  When  there  is  no  agreement  on  foreclosure  in  the  mortgage  contract,  Decree  163 
outlines the various steps for judicial foreclosure. If the case is brought to the court, it can take 
much  more  time  for  the  issuing  and  implementing  of  the  court  decision,  given  the  unclear 
summary  judgment  procedure  and  the  poor  effectiveness  of  the  judicial  police  responsible  for 
implementation of the court system. Judicial foreclosure has been tested to a limited extent with 
successful outcomes.
